Package org.apache.clusterbr

package org.apache.clusterbr

Unit tests and integration tests are two essential testing types that ensure a program functions correctly, but they focus on different aspects.

Unit Test

Unit tests are like examining the small parts of a machine separately to ensure each one works. They focus on testing individual pieces of code, such as methods or functions, without considering their interaction with other system parts.

Unit tests are lightweight and quick to execute since they don’t depend on external systems. They are ideal for identifying bugs early when working on specific parts of the code.

Integration Test

Integration tests are like assembling parts of a machine together to check if they work as a whole. These tests verify how different components of the system interact with each other.

Unlike unit tests, integration tests often involve many dependencies, such as databases or external services, to ensure the entire process functions correctly. These tests take longer to execute because they usually require a full setup, like loading the application context and establishing database or service connections.

Integration tests are more comprehensive and help detect issues that arise when different parts of the program collaborate.

Why Use Both?

By using both unit tests and integration tests, development-team ensures a robust and reliable application. Unit tests provide quick feedback for small pieces of code, while integration tests validate that the overall system works as expected. Together, they cover the code’s behavior at different levels and increase confidence in the software's quality.
